We know full well that our planet and all its inhabitants are but a small part of the immense universe that surrounds us and it is with humility and hope that we take this step.

According to the book, traveling far distances is now possible thanks to “somaforming”, a biological engineering process whereby the astronauts themselves can survive long periods of suspended animation and exploration on different planets by undergoing temporary genetic changes. These modifications allow them to survive heavier or lighter gravities by developing extra muscle fiber, or glittering skin to reduce exposure to radiation, or other changes to cope with extremes in climate and so on. During each of their long sleep periods, they are suspended in torpor chambers and physically modified depending on which planet they will next land on and explore.

The four exoplanets (worlds that don’t orbit our sun) that the crew of mission specialists explore are each highly individualized and radically different, requiring different genetic modifications. The four crew members are also distinctly different, ranging from a talented engineer to a passionate biologist, yet they work well as a team, sometimes sharing their beds and sometimes becoming so intensely involved with studying the four planets that they become isolated within themselves.

The book opens with the narrator, Ariadne, one of the crew of the deep space explorer Merian, asking the reader of her log entries to read everything she has written, rather than skipping to the end. Apparently by immersing ourselves in the crew’s experiences, we as readers will be better placed to reach a decision armed with all relevant facts. The log entries each take 14 years to reach Earth and receiving a reply takes another 14 years, so by the time the crew has explored all four worlds, they will have been away from Earth for several decades. There are indications that all is not good on the Earth the crew has left behind, and the question Ariadne and her companions need answered is whether they should go back home, or settle on one of the planets, or return to their torpor chambers to await a decision from Earth that may never come.

I enjoyed reading about each of the four exoplanets explored, starting with Aecor, an ice world with life swirling beneath its frozen surface. The crew relish their time there and make some important biological discoveries. Next is Mirabilis, a world teeming with plant and animal life that is endlessly fascinating and reminds me a bit of James Cameron’s Pandora in the film Avatar. The author’s writing style is always imaginative and engaging, so that I became quickly immersed along with the crew of the Merian as they explore each world. It is on the third planet, Opera, however, that things take a depressing turn, given that the crew hasn’t received any communications from Earth for the past five years. They are almost unable to land, given that there is very little land and a lot of water covering the planet. What is worse is when the ship does land, it quickly becomes covered by indigenous creatures that basically cover the entire exterior of the ship, including the windows, and prevent the crew from even leaving the ship to explore. The depiction of each crew member’s descent into depression, compounded by the endless squealing and sucking noises emitted by the creatures, is very effectively done.

Eventually the crew decides to leave Opera, having spent several months trapped onboard with very little to do, and makes their way to the fourth and final planet on their list, Votum. This wasteland of a planet is perpetually locked with one side in full light, the other in eternal darkness. But at least it is somewhere the crew can actually explore and not be trapped within the ship. They make a startling discovery (my grasp of science is tenuous, so I only got the main idea that life didn’t originate on Earth) and devote the rest of their three and a half years’ allocated time on Votum doing cataloguing and research, and along the way regaining their mental equilibrium.

The book ends unresolved. Where should the crew go next if they don’t return to a possibly lifeless Earth? Their mission is to catalogue, not colonise. There is the Tivael system, which has three other exoplanets that may also have sustainable life. They don’t see that they have the right to make the decision, however, so this is left to the reader, who stands in for whatever decision-making body might remain on Earth.

This is what made this book ultimately unsatisfactory for me – the dangling, unresolved nature of the crew’s decision. I felt I had just spent years with these people, suffering and celebrating along with them, and to then have such an open-ended conclusion feels like a cop-out. I can see what the author is trying to do, which is to get the reader to make a morally or ethically based decision themselves, having gone on the journey. But what it does instead, for me at any rate, is turn the book into an episodic series of incidents, stop-overs on different worlds, with not a lot of anything gained overall by the time the fourth planet is visited.

The book reminded me of the excellent Christopher Nolan film Interstellar, which also saw astronauts set out on missions to find other habitable worlds, given that Earth was becoming unviable. Those astronauts’ journey passed in just days, weeks and months for them, but years and decades elapsed for those left behind on Earth. The astronauts explored other worlds, which were vastly different from each other, and this was particularly where I felt there was a connection to the To Be Taught book. Interstellar did it better, I believe, mainly because the exploration led to a resolution, a sense of moving on, progressing, learning from mistakes and trying to ensure that the mistakes of the past were not taken with humanity as it headed out into the stars.

An enthusiastic review I read recently on a social media feed led me to buy The Long Way to a Small Angry Planet, a 2014 novel by Becky Chambers. I know I’ve come a bit late to discovering this work, but I’m always looking for previously unheard of, interesting or different SF to read, something that creates a buzz of excitement. One critic described it “as though Firefly and Guardians of the Galaxy had one hyperactive and excited baby”. Having read it I can admire its depth, characterisation and world building, but it seems to share its roots with what has come before, classics such as ALIEN, ALIENS, Starship Troopers, Bladerunner, Almost Human, Firefly and many other excellent SF films and TV series.

This doesn’t make The Long Way to a Small Angry Planet a disappointing entry in the genre, just one that is sometimes derivative or induces a sense of déjà vu. As Han Solo in Star Wars said, “didn’t we just leave this party?”

Author Becky Chambers has an impressive resumé that makes her ideally suited to write SF themed novels. Raised by parents with interests or careers in astrobiology, aerospace engineering and rocket science, this novel is littered with space faring jargon and whole pages of conversational exposition describing tunnelling through space, interplanetary wars, character histories, the latest tech and other space-based activities. Not being science-savvy, despite loving to read SF novels, I was totally out of my depth when reading the stuff on space tunnelling, and despite re-reading it in the vain hope I would come to understand what was involved, I couldn’t grasp the technicalities because, dammit, Spock, I’m not a physicist!

What books such as this, or films like ALIEN and ALIENS, or TV series such as Firefly, do and do so well, is create believable SF scenarios by populating them with realistic, engaging characters. Whether they are gung-ho military types, socially awkward science boffins or grunts eking an existence as grease-stained space jockeys, their humanity, flaws, ambitions, and interactions with those around them make the time spent with them enjoyable. I might not know what a “modder” or “imubot” actually is, but I can grasp enough to get by and keep reading. They are details, background, colour and flavour, but I don’t mind if I can’t picture them all.

Like the newbie Rosemary Harper who comes onboard the Wayfarer tunnelling space craft at the beginning of The Long Way to a Small Angry Planet to work as a glorified clerical assistant, I was similarly awed and confused by the ship’s environment and species-diverse crew. She has to familiarise herself with the different races and species onboard, treading carefully to avoid making cultural, gender or linguistic gaffes. I enjoyed the naturalist, overlapping dialogue peppered with pop cultural references, which sometimes reminded me of the exchanges between Brett and Parker in ALIEN. It was reassuring to know that in the future not everyone talks about noble stuff all the time but just ordinary, everyday things.

The more I read, the clearer it became that this novel’s focus was on the characters and their personal journeys, with different chapters being devoted to learning more about everyone’s backstory, especially if they happened to be visiting a home world or a place where they might meet someone important from their past, or an event that triggered a painful memory. This was done more successfully for some characters than others, and tended to give the narrative structure a predictable feeling, that sense of, okay, whose backstory am I going to read about next? There was a definite sense that this book was more concerned with the characters and less with action. There are a handful of scenes that are a bit shocking or emotionally charged, because they come out of nowhere, disrupting the cosy, comfortable onboard routine of each character that we get to know like a friend. These scenes finally move the action along, but it’s obvious it isn’t the arrival at the destination that is front and centre but getting there that matters, hence the title’s reference to being a long way.

Not all the crew get along, which makes the unfolding story more interesting and realistic. The ship’s algaeist, Artis Corbin, who prefers to tend to his algae tanks in his lab than interact with his crewmates, is viewed by the others as being anti-social, grumpy and very difficult to get along with (almost as though he was an android). When I finally learned more about his past, and how something he experienced during the voyage led to a change in his behaviour, it was a bit too little too late. I had expected more of a surprise, rather than the predictable father-son clash (despite the unusual nature of their connection). He was one character that didn’t get, or perhaps warrant, more space in this novel. I also found the rather contrived situation where he owed his release from a tricky situation to the one crew member that he clashed with the most to be a bit too much of a coincidence.

More interesting and successful character arcs and interactions came mainly from the reptilian pilot Sissix, an Aandrisk, with feathers, scales and a tail, who loves to demonstrate physical affection but finds it hard to do so among standoffish humans. She has a close, platonic relationship with the ship’s human captain Ashby, who grew up on an Earth Exodus fleet ship. Their relationship reminded me strongly of the one between Malcolm Reynolds and Zoe from Firefly, although I kept picturing Ashby looking like Phil Coulson from The Agents of SHIELD.

Sissix and one of the crew become romantically involved, and the way the same-sex relationship unfolds and is depicted avoids any sensationalism or prurience – it is so delicately and respectfully handled. No less touching is the odd relationship between the ship’s AI, Lovey (short for Lovelace), who reminded me strongly (in terms of her personality) of Helva from The Ship Who Sang by Anne McCaffrey [1969]. Lovey runs the ship, is aware of all its functions, and keeps a motherly eye on the crew as well. She is especially close to Jenks, one of the ship technicians, a stunted human who has resisted having any “genetweaks” to correct his short stature (again, he reminded me a bit of Helva’s boss Niall Parollan in The Ship Who Sang). Jenks and Lovey enjoy a close, loving relationship despite their physical barriers, and it was very satisfying to see an AI depicted as another sentient being.

Jenks is also best buddies with another human tech, Kizzy Shao, who reminded me of the ship’s mechanic Kaylee in Firefly, as both are fond of wearing overalls or scruffy clothes, tend to be covered in grease and gunk, but are wizards with anything mechanical. Kizzy and Jenks spend their down time enthusing over new games, music, food, and their conversations are among some of the most entertaining and believable in this novel.

Less easy to accept was what amounted to seismic character shifts in some of the crew, who were so adamantly one way in their thinking or entire upbringing, and yet had a change of heart that was almost like a personality transplant, and this was something I could have done without.

The climax of the story, involving tunnelling (creating a kind of hyperspace conduit to a distant planet, akin to folding space in Dune [book, 1969]) while trying to survive crossing through hostile, often war-ravaged interstellar space, felt a bit rushed, even awkward. The tunnel is being constructed so that the potential new members of the GC (Galactic Council), an extremely war-like race, the Toremi Ka, can be more easily accessed by the rest of the galaxy. Some members of the GC Parliament are prepared to overlook the Toremi Ka’s hostile tendencies because of the potential access to a highly desirable and much sought-after fuel substance, ambi.

It takes a stirring speech from Captain Ashby to make the Council re-assess its priorities. This part of the book reminded me of the climax in The Mote in God’s Eye [1974] by Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle, only not nearly as exciting or nail-bitingly intense.

I had also forgotten most of the backstory about the Toremi Ka because it was described much earlier in the novel, and I couldn’t be bothered going back to find and re-read it, although I took more note of it during my second reading. Some of the information about this race is conveyed through the space equivalent of emails between Rosemary and someone she met on one of the Wayfarer’s stopovers. Another rather far-fetched moment occurs when an email containing crucial information about the Toremi Ka just happens to bounce back so Rosemary doesn’t get to read it in time, which seemed to be a clumsy bit of plotting.

I often re-read favourite novels because they are comfortable and comforting, the mental equivalent of snuggling into an old jumper or blanket. I know what is coming, how events will unfold, who will die, who will live, and despite that I still enjoy them every time. It’s all to do with the way they are written, the world building, the little imaginative touches that can convey so much. The writing is engaging, unself-conscious, not even something I notice as I am so caught up in what the writing is conveying – the characters, their stories and interactions (except for those pesky scientific bits that make my brain hurt).

The Long Way to a Small Angry Planet is a bit like that – its writing style, character depiction and interactions are very engaging, and although I struggled to grasp unfamiliar science concepts, I wanted to keep reading it to the end because I liked the characters and was curious to see how they coped. Despite this warm and fuzzy feeling, I still felt disappointed that the plot and situations never seemed entirely new, original, or unique. I was often reminded of or distracted by the underlying foundations, the long lineage and influence of other SF novels, films and TV series that have preceded it. Maybe it was because of the similarities, the sense that there is nothing new under this or any other sun, that I can’t give it a perfect score. Yet I certainly enjoyed this novel enough, once finished, to immediately order the next three books in the Wayfarer series. I hope they are as enjoyable and satisfying overall to read as this first one was, but without reminding me so much of all those other works I have read leading up to this moment.

Way back in 1978 I sat through (or more accurately endured with terror) the original science fiction horror masterpiece ALIEN, directed by Ridley Scott. I am a science fiction fan, not a horror fan, so there was an uncomfortable dichotomy in this film that made it difficult to sit through that first time. But watch it I did, and I have watched this movie repeatedly over the years since then, having fallen under its compelling spell. It remains a classic, re-watchable favourite on so many levels.

Upon its initial release some critics bemoaned the ‘haunted house in space’ scenario, and what they saw as forgettable or indistinguishable characters (not including Ripley). Conversely what I savoured about that film were the beautifully convincing, grittily real sets, which were explored lovingly prior to the crew’s re-awakening; the haunting, chillingly alien landscape with its windswept desolation; and the unstoppable, deadly force that was unleashed on a naïve, hapless crew that basically had no training to deal with this sort of situation. Over time each character became a clearly delineated person with obvious quirks, who enjoyed some convincing by-play with each other. It made watching almost all of them meet an unpleasant demise truly sad, because they were never meant to deal with this thing from out there. I loved the innovative, poignant soundtrack score by Jerry Goldsmith (which I still have as an original record from back in the days when we used turntables for real rather than novelty value).

I love the fact that even at the direst of moments Ripley could still spare a thought for Jones, the ship’s cat. Ripley’s growth from cocky, something-to-prove lieutenant to hero par excellence was a joy to watch and share. (It reminds me of that amusing meme about someone saying they knew their new romance wasn’t going to last because their partner couldn’t understand why Ripley would go back for the cat.)

Space was just another work environment, and the crew of the massive ore refinery were just blue-collar types trying to earn a living doing an unglamorous job. They weren’t heroes, soldiers or explorers, and their employers basically left them defenceless against an alien organism that had weapons potential. This is a slow burn of a film, leisurely paced at first, with brief bursts of shocking violence, escalating to a life or death battle and the triumph by a person who will never be the same. The humanity and science fiction setting won over my dislike of horror, although to this day I still cannot watch the first face hugger take down John Hurt’s character Kane on the alien ship.

James Cameron’s sequel, ALIENS (1986), had it all there in the title, being a more straight-forward science fiction drama, with the gung-ho Colonial marines no match for Ripley’s nightmarish monsters. I enjoy watching this film repeatedly for different reasons, mainly because it is just such rollicking good fun, with black humour and stunning action sequences, built around a cast of memorable, engaging characters.
